Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: The magnetized multi-phase interstellar medium

POR.DRECONTENT:
Gas in the space between the stars in our Milky Way Galaxy, called the "interstellar medium", is crucial to the evolution of the Galaxy and to the formation and life cycle of stars, including the Sun. Although the interstellar medium is much less dense than the best laboratory vacuum on Earth, new stars form out of this gas, and dying stars return matter to the gas. When the most massive stars die, they explode as supernovae, the most energetic events in the Galaxy. These explosions create turbulence in the interstellar medium, which in turn creates structures ranging from the size of our Solar System to many light-years across.


In this project, we compared observations that are sensitive to the magnetic field to observations sensitive to the amount of charged particles within the interstellar medium. An all-sky map of polarization from distant radio sources provides information about the magnetic field, while the observations of charged hydrogen gas use visible light measured with the Wisconsin H-Alpha Mapper (WHAM). We found evidence for small-scale turbulence that would be difficult or impossible to detect using traditional techniques. Through this work, we learn about how energy is transported from dying stars through the interstellar medium, perhaps leading to the collapse of new stars.
